title: Exempts individual or group policies of medicare supplemental insurance from certain provisions regarding increase or decrease of premiums
summary: Exempts individual or group policies of medicare supplemental insurance from certain provisions regarding increase or decrease of premiums without a public hearing.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2314

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the insurance law, in relation to individual or group
policies of medicare supplemental insurance

PURPOSE/SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Amends subsection (e) of section 3231 of the insurance law, as added by
chapter 501 of the laws of 1992, and section 4308 of the insurance law
as added by chapter 504 of the laws of 1995.

JUSTIFICATION:
Presently, the Department of Insurance (DOI) is not authorized to
convene public hearings to review the merits of requests that are filed
by insurance carriers to increase the premiums of health care insurance
policies by 10%. As a result, recent dramatic increases in medicare
supplemental insurance policies have been approved without the public
having the opportunity to express their concerns and ensure such
requests are warranted. Such increases have the potential to jeopardize
older New Yorkers' access to the vital coverage provided by these poli-
cies. This bill would require the DOI to convene public hearings on
proposed increases in premiums for medicare supplemental insurance poli-
cies.

Since the DOI as indicated that double-digit increases in such policies
are becoming an emerging trend, every effort must be made available to
ensure that such increases are truly justified. Based on income data, it
is obvious many senior citizens, and most especially those living on
fixed or modest incomes, will find it difficult, if not impossible, to
absorb future increases in the costs associated with obtaining these
policies. This is especially problematic for many seniors who subscribe
to supplemental insurance as a means to control their health care costs.
Also, such requests must be viewed in the wider context of the huge cuts
and changes in Medicare that are being considered by Congress. With so
much uncertainty about the impact on elderly New Yorkers of these chang-
es it is essential that the DOI convene public hearings to investigate
the merit of such increases.

In addition, these public events would ensure attention would be focused
on the administrative costs associated with offering these policies and
to review the insurer's fraud and detection efforts.

EXISTING LAW:
1997-98: A.4471/S.2685 - Passed Assembly
1995-97: A.8859/S.6293 - Passed Assembly

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
1st day of April after it shall have become law.
